new_citizenship_descent.criteria: Any person whose father or mother is a citizen of Nepal at the time of their birth. The applicant must be at least 16 years old.
required_documents: Copy of the Nepali citizenship certificate of the father, mother, or a relative within three generations of the lineage.
Recommendation from the Village Development Committee or Municipality (Ward Office) certifying birth records and relationship
Note: For children of a Nepali female citizen married to a foreign citizen, specific naturalization rules apply.
new_citizenship_descent.process: Submit the application and documents to the designated authority (typically the CDO at the District Administration Office). If documents are missing, the authority may conduct an on-site inquiry and require witness signatures from three local citizens.

lost_destroyed_citizenship.criteria: If a citizenship certificate is lost or destroyed, or if details need correction (such as minor errors in name or age).
required_documents: Application for a duplicate (Pratilipi) along with necessary evidence of the loss or the error.
In case of relocation (migration), the previous citizenship certificate must be surrendered to receive a new one with the updated address.
lost_destroyed_citizenship.process: The designated officer will examine the evidence and may conduct a witness inquiry (Sarjamin) before issuing a duplicate or corrected certificate.

important_legal_notes.penalties: Providing false information to obtain citizenship can result in 1 to 5 years of imprisonment or a fine of 50,000 to 100,000 NPR.
important_legal_notes.dual_citizenship: Nepal does not allow dual citizenship; Nepali citizenship is automatically lost upon voluntarily acquiring foreign citizenship.
